newsitem.title: JAPAN: Suzutan president says share sale not illegal.
newsitem.headline: Suzutan president says share sale not illegal.

text.p: Suzutan Co Ltd president Katsurao Suzui said on Monday that he sold shares in the retailer prior to its announcement of a loss for the 1994/95 business year, but added he did not regard this as improper insider trading.
A source close to the Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission said earlier that the commission had begun a probe into alleged improper insider trading by Suzui.
Suzui was quoted by a company official as saying he sold shares in the middle of 1994 to pay back bank loans.

"The sales of shares were intended for repayment of loans for my personal enterprise. I believe that the transactions would not be characterised as insider trading," the officials quoted Suzui as saying.
The official said Suzui, then chairman of the company, sold about 1.01 million Suzutan shares worth 1.26 billion yen to banks in the period from May to August 1994.

In the following year, Suzutan posted a 6.6 billion yen extraordinary loss for the 1994/95 business year to February due to a write-off of losses from a majority-owned subsidiary that develops shopping centres. The company incurred a net loss of seven billion yen that year.
Media reports said that, following the loss announcement, shares in the company plunged to around 900 yen from 1,300 yen on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Suzutan is a women's wear retailer based in Nagoya. Its shares closed down 19 points at 447 on Monday.
